pros: A nice place to work with great benefits.
cons: Some days can be a little hectic.

review_title: Doomed to fail under current leadership.
pros: Many learning opportunities Nice location in AZ Mostly good colleagues
cons: Horrible management at the top that uses shady practices. Nepotism and cronyism are valued over employee skill and experience. No transparency. Coercive leadership styles are the norm.

pros: easy commute close to home
cons: Low pay, poor leadership, poor HR.

pros: Co-Workers are supportive and ATSU is an overall great place to work.
cons: Compensation is low for support staff.

pros: Amazing coworkers, better pay than average for higher ed, the BEST benefits. Having worked for both public and private institutions, ATSU pays significantly more and has much better benefits than AZ public universities. The university closes between Christmas Eve and NYE so you always get some sort of winter break without using vacation time. Being a health professions institution, they have an excellent program to help you stay healthy including 30 minutes off for 3 days per week for fitness (at supervisor's discretion) and access to frequent seminars focused on health and wellness. During the pandemic, rather than furloughing or laying off employees as most schools and companies did, ATSU retained their employees and even gave them a bonus at the end of 2020 plus an extra 4 days of vacation. You get vacation time plus 3 personal days per year. Lots of opportunities for professional development too. By far the best place I have ever worked.
cons: Poor work/life balance. The ONLY con is that the Mesa staff are often burned out. Being a campus-wide department, we serve many more academic programs and students than the Kirksville campus, yet it is a common belief that Kirksville gets all of the support. If a new position is created, it is likely located in Kirksville. Almost all of the management is in Kirksville too, so your supervisor will likely not be on the same campus, which can be difficult at times. Turnover is pretty low, but when people do leave the department, it is because they feel overworked and burned out.

pros: Great benefits package, flexible schedule
cons: Very toxic, overworked, poor leadership

review_title: Terrible Company, terrible pay, terrible work conditions
job_title: Clinical Education Coordinator in Queen Creek, AZ
pros: Two weeks paid vacation at end of year. One day telecommuting. Good immediate supervisor, great co-workers.
cons: Terrible pay, no pay increases, short staffed, overworked, consistently taking away perks, made to drive into the office for a job that could be done at home.

review_title: Good stepping stone, but not much growth for employees.

cons:
Org is bloated with upper administration and the right hand never knows what the left hand is doing.
There is no career advancement, pay in extremely low and ability to make positive changes are generally cut off due to short sighted management. Some administrators don't trust the employees they hired.

job_title: Dental Instructor Simulation Clinic in Mesa, AZ
pros: Great sense of team. It is a rewarding experience to be a part of supporting young up and coming dentists. This work can be exhausting as you are on your feet for several hours in the day. But, if you love to support and instruct and be a positive role model and example for young learners who are looking to become their very best then the tired feet are worth it.
cons: Does not pay as well as it should but nonetheless, a wonderful opportunity.

pros: We came to Kirksville planning a quick stop on the way to somewhere else. It turned into our home because of ATSU. The school has blessed me with endless opportunity.
cons: It is a rural area, so city slickers can have a tough time adjusting.

review_title: Happy to be part of the team
pros: I'm a part of a really great team that works really well together. ATSU lives the mission in everything that is done on campus, off-campus, and through any affiliates. I'm proud to be a part of the ATSU family.
cons: Can't think of anything to add here.

pros: School provides great experiences and knowledgeable faculty
cons: Cost of tuition is high

review_title: Challenging environment, but unrewarding for a staff member
pros:
- Having the opportunity to work with students is very rewarding.
- Most people on campus are very friendly and professional. The campus grounds are beautiful.
- A telecommute policy was recently instituted which now allows staff members to work from home one day per week with their supervisor's approval.
- All staff and faculty receive an additional week or so of paid holiday leave around the holidays every year.
cons:
- This is an educational institution that does not offer any educational/training opportunities for staff, unless you already have a Bachelor's degree which many staff members do not possess. There is a training fund for staff, which is currently being funded by donations.
- Administration and faculty use fear mongering techniques to keep staff members, "in line."
- The HR department is useless. Many policies include the stipulation, "up to your manager's discretion." This causes quite a bit of discord between departments. Further, even though the HR department serves both the Mesa and Kirksville, MO, campuses, there seems to be a lack of communication between the two sites.
- There is very little opportunity for job growth. The only options for staff are to stay in your current role and receive yearly cost of living wage raises, move to another staff role within the university, or earn a Master's degree and try to become a faculty member.
- There is a strong class divide between faculty and staff members. The culture within the organization only reinforces the divide.
- Departments are frequently understaffed.
- Staff members are now required to punch a time clock everyday.

review_title: Great Students and Excellent Library System
pros:
Highly motivated students
Excellent library - very helpful librarians
cons:
Unrealistic expectations about research in light of teaching load.
Work life balance is not ideal for faculty

pros:

Supportive 
CE allowance

cons: New admin are not supportive and doesnt respect personal growth goals

pros: Quiet working environment, good benefits, well-respected positions . Great place to learn about political maneuvering. Few people have an opportunity to see so many moves, and, I learned a lot which helped my career skyrocket after I left the university.
cons: Sharp status division between teaching faculty and staff.  Faculty had access to locked break room, staff did have a break room. Staff, even those in professional jobs,  with Masters degrees  (especially female staff) were expected to keep the coffee pot full for the male teaching faculty.  Patriarchy abounded in the departments, which tended to be soloed and competitive. The university was extremely political, with faculty members being outwardly friendly but silently working to upsurp each other (to attain their higher position).

pros:
ATSU is one of the best places I have ever worked! Morale in my department is exceptionally high. We share space with several other departments and it's truly a pleasure to come to work!

SUPERVISION: Company policy provides autonomy to supervisors who in turn are responsible for executing skilled leadership in running their departments, ensuring good moral & efficient work output. I am fortunate to work for one of the best supervisors in our university and have found flexible policies ensure our department is able to perform at a superior level. 

HR: Their knowledge of university programs and policies has been immensely helpful over my many years of employ. Honor and integrity are core values evident when one walks through their door. Dedication (to staff, students & university); fairness; equity; and a proactive demeanor permeate everything they touch. ATSU's HR department provides some of the best customer service I've ever experienced. Never have I seen a harder working group of people. 

TRAINING: Annual training has been streamlined leaving one feeling the authors truly understand how valuable their product is. Kudos to the team for designing a training package which is user friendly, targeted, memorable and time sensitive. 

BENEFITS: Benefits are excellent! I am particularly impressed by the Health & Wellness program employees are encouraged to partake in resulting in improved personal health and reduced insurance costs! ATSU subsidizes our benefit package ensuring every employee can afford insurance coverage! We are always kept abreast of current mandates. BRAVO and thank you for all you do for us!

ADVANCEMENT: Hard work and positive attitudes ARE recognized! ATSU has an awesome recognition program. I've personally witnessed support of employees on a quest for self improvement, professional improvement and general progression within the confines of ATSU. Everyone benefits when our dynamic supervisors and employees engage.
cons:
SUPERVISION: Company policy provides autonomy to supervisors who in turn are responsible for executing skilled leadership. Whilst I work for an exceptional supervisor, as in any large company it's quite possible not everyone is as fortunate. Our benefits have the potential of being a double edged sword. Anyone unfortunate enough to work for a supervisor in need of "additional training" has a responsibility to discuss the matter with a department that can help. HR and Diversity come readily to mind, along with the multiple Safe Zone volunteers around the university. Keeping silent does not bode well for the employee, supervisor or university. It is  everyone's duty to recognize and call out those cancerous elements of the human psyche that make for a less than harmonious working environment. 

BENEFITS:  The downside of excellent benefits is that sometimes mediocrity chooses not to move on. It's hard to find other companies with a benefit package as good as ours. Because our HR department goes to great lengths to help disgruntled employees find a path to "enlightenment", I've found there have been, on occasion, employees who create a difficult working environment for others. If things weren't as good at our university I would expect those people to move on - but they don't. I don't feel this is a huge problem because it's apparent by the quality of employees/students at ATSU that leadership goes to great lengths to find the "right" people for the job.

COMMUNICATION: ATSU is afflicted with bureaucracy, as is most large institutions. In recent past I've seen a concerted effort to modernize our procedures. I am confident communication will equalize as our upgrades come to fruition.

pros: Warm, family-friendly culture on two campuses (Missouri and Arizona), each of which is extremely student-centered. People truly care about each other at this institution, and work hard to be the best professional example in health care education. University is continually looking at how to be more innovative, and is currently undergoing significant expansion, which is exciting! They are always looking toward the future.
cons: Sometimes, it is difficult to attract people to the Missouri campus location, since it is more rural. However, once they get here, they typically fall in love with it, and often never want to leave!

pros: I'm sure the experience is different depending on what program/department you work for, but my team is incredible. There is a very positive work culture. Although there are limited opportunities for promotional advancement, I feel like my work is appreciated, and I have opportunities to take on new experiences, increased responsibilities, and participate in conferences/professional development. The benefits are amazing, especially time off. Both campuses include a gym membership for F/T employees. Great work/life balance. Most positions allow for some travel between the campuses, which is a lot of fun.
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement

pros: Benefits and  professional development opportunities, work-life balance, interprofessional collaboration,  mission, interesting and educated coworkers who enjoy the sport of a challenging work environment
cons: Low salary, lack of communication,  insufficient IT provisioning, zero based budgeting and overall budget process, lack of sufficient budget support, small town and large urban cultural misalignment

pros: Good people. Friendly people within each department. Departments work well together. Management is easy to work with. I enjoyed my time there.
cons: No cons really. Maybe better pay and more frequent performance evaluations from various levels. Clearer route to advancement would be nice.

pros: I enjoyed working with the distance students and faculty.
cons: I thought the university counsel and administrators had unethical practices.  The HR staff sucked!  I would not recommend working here to anyone!  Run away!!

review_title: The Devil IS IN the details
pros: Benefits are decent, campus is nice.
cons: Don't feel valued, management of workload is not fairly distributed.  There is too much chaos to ever find common ground or get answers in this regard.  Favoritism runs deep here.
